> The other problem is that I don't know if it is possible to load a new .obj at each frame when new triangles have been added to .obj file

You can write to the GL context as long as you're in a GL thread. In samplerender, that's either in onSurfaceCreated or in onDrawFrame. That means you would be able to load your mesh in onDrawFrame, though be sure to profile the performance hit if you're doing it too often. If you know all of the meshes in advance, you could load them all in onSurfaceCreated and swap out which mesh is being used to render [here](https://github.com/google-ar/arcore-android-sdk/blob/e271aa3304afae21a1f64a1e2e5bd82ee44d49e3/samples/hello_ar_kotlin/app/src/main/java/com/google/ar/core/examples/kotlin/helloar/HelloArRenderer.kt#L407). 

> I want to have semi transparent triangles with colored lines for the triangles.

You'd need to [write a fragment shader](https://learnopengl.com/Getting-started/Shaders) that can render a wireframe and appropriately colors your object's faces. Probably you'd use [Barycentric Coordinates](https://www.scratchapixel.com/lessons/3d-basic-rendering/ray-tracing-rendering-a-triangle/barycentric-coordinates) to determine the distance to the edge of the triangle, and use your "wireframe" color, and otherwise the semi-transparent fill color.

Hope this helps a little, though I'll close this for not being related to the ARCore SDK.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/google-ar/arcore-android-sdk/issues/comments/1078846106/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

> * Prefer [CameraConfig.StereoCameraUsage.REQUIRE_AND_USE](https://developers.google.com/ar/reference/java/com/google/ar/core/CameraConfig.StereoCameraUsage#REQUIRE_AND_USE) over [CameraConfig.StereoCameraUsage.DO_NOT_USE](https://developers.google.com/ar/reference/java/com/google/ar/core/CameraConfig.StereoCameraUsage#DO_NOT_USE)
> * Prefer [CameraConfig.TargetFps.TARGET_FPS_60](https://developers.google.com/ar/reference/java/com/google/ar/core/CameraConfig.TargetFps#TARGET_FPS_60) over [CameraConfig.TargetFps.TARGET_FPS_30](https://developers.google.com/ar/reference/java/com/google/ar/core/CameraConfig.TargetFps#TARGET_FPS_30)
> * Prefer [CameraConfig.DepthSensorUsage.REQUIRE_AND_USE](https://developers.google.com/ar/reference/java/com/google/ar/core/CameraConfig.DepthSensorUsage#REQUIRE_AND_USE) over [CameraConfig.DepthSensorUsage.DO_NOT_USE](https://developers.google.com/ar/reference/java/com/google/ar/core/CameraConfig.DepthSensorUsage#DO_NOT_USE)
> 
> No guarantees are made about the order in which the remaining elements are returned.

The reason why the FPS increases to 60 FPS is because of these rules, in which 60 FPS profiles come before 30 FPS profiles.

If you want everything the same except DepthSensorUsage from ON to OFF, you could try the following snippet:

```
    val filter = CameraConfigFilter(session).apply {
      val currentConfig = session.cameraConfig
      this.facingDirection = currentConfig.facingDirection
      this.stereoCameraUsage = EnumSet.of(currentConfig.stereoCameraUsage)

      this.depthSensorUsage = EnumSet.of(CameraConfig.DepthSensorUsage.DO_NOT_USE)
      this.targetFps = EnumSet.of(if (currentConfig.fpsRange.upper >= 60) CameraConfig.TargetFps.TARGET_FPS_60 else CameraConfig.TargetFps.TARGET_FPS_30)
    }
```

Then selecting one of the camera configs that suits your needs best (arising from processing times for larger CPU and GPU textures).

As Michael mentioned on the question, indeed, the position of an element in the point cloud buffer is important. For example, point number 15 has coordinates `(point_cloud_data[14*4], point_cloud_data[14*4+1]. point_cloud_data[14*4+2])`, where `point_cloud_data` is the result of [`ArPointCloud_getData`](https://developers.google.com/ar/reference/c/group/ar-point-cloud#arpointcloud_getdata). The ID of this point is the 15th entry of the point cloud ID array, i.e. `point_ids[14]`.

There isn't a way to construct an ArPoint given an ArPointCloud; ArPoints come from `hitTest`'s [`ArHitResult_acquireTrackable`](https://developers.google.com/ar/reference/c/group/ar-hit-result#arhitresult_acquiretrackable).

> Question: How can a unique identifier (point id) be used to get the X, Y, Z, confidence level for a single unique point ?

Something like this:

* Iterate over `0.. ArPointCloud_getNumberOfPoints`,
* Find index of interest in `ArPointCloud_getPointIds`,
* Use index to lookup values in `ArPointCloud_getData`.
